Title: Cult of the Dead Cow: How the Original Hacking Supergroup Might Just Save the World

Title: The Rise and Fall of D.O.D.O.
Author: Neal Stephenson
My Review: Neal Stephenson has a powerful ability to write fiction that changes the way you see the world even when youâ€™ve paused or long finished reading. This book is in the same vein but less academic and more driving than I found his other books like Quicksilver. The case made here for the hidden and under utilized power of dormant magic, as defined here, and witchcraft is incredibly compelling. It provides a lens through which you can re-read history and entertain the idea of how magic might have influenced well-known events.

Title: Theft by Finding: Diaries (1977-2002)
Author: David Sedaris
My Review: Sedaris' diary entries are so funny, so honest, ranging from charmingly ordinary to unbelievable. I dare you to read this and not feel compelled to keep a diary afterwards. Sedaris, like any great artist, makes an incredibly difficult task appear effortless.

Title: Kids These Days: Human Capital and the Making of Millennials
Author: Malcolm   Harris
My Review: It feels good to read someone smart take things you understand and feel intuitively about the world and back them up with intelligent arguments and research. This is a frank contextual guide for younger millenials or gen-xers to understand some of the immediate history that created the invisible mechanisms that are shaping our society.

Title: Manage Your Day-to-Day: Build Your Routine, Find Your Focus, and Sharpen Your Creative Mind
Author: Jocelyn K. Glei
My Review:
I found this book very inspiring, I read it before bed and often found myself excited to wake up the next morning to try working with some of the techniques.

The insight I found most practically useful was the idea of scheduling out blocked "focused work" times. As a freelancer, sometimes the lack of a clear 9-to-5 can make it hard to balance life and work. Setting aside time when you are booked to work is a smart way of making consistent work a habit, and helps you defend your productive time from intrusions.

I also really liked the idea of thinking using different perspectives when at a creative block. "How would my old teacher solve this? How would a 5-year-old solve it? How would Steve Jobs solve it?"

A quick read, like a buffet of techniques. Not all of it applied, but I was able to pick one the parts that did and they were very helpful.
